text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen 
now I've used curry paste in several of

my recipes and many of you hardcore cooks 
have requested recipe for how to make curry

paste from scratch so finally today it is the 
opportune time for that recipe today I'm making

prik gang ped translated in English as red 
curry paste and I'm choosing to do that one

because it's actually the most basic and the 
most versatile one all the other curries such

as massaman or Panang or even green yellow 
curry all kind of build upon this one as

a base so if you know this one you're already 
halfway there there with all the other curries

there are ten curry paste ingredients that are 
basic the basic tent so let's start first we

have the chilies now chilies we're using red dried 
chilies and there are larger chilies and we first

need to rehydrate them but before you rehydrate 
them you want to take out all the seats and you

do that by just cutting it horizontally opening 
it up well this one doesn't have too many seeds

and pull out the pit and the seeds from the 
inside make sure everything is gone so the

reason why we're removing the seeds and the pith 
is because this is our source of red color so you

want to maximize the amount of chilies we can fit 
in without it being too spicy so the pith and the

seeds are really spicy so by removing them we 
can fit in more red color and also the pith and

the seeds are not red so it'll dilute the color of 
our red curry paste we're so bad for several hours

until they swell up and become fully rehydrated 
just like that actually did this last night and

then what you do so we're using 7 to 15 however 
much you want depending on how spicy you want

and then you want to drain it all off and then 
you want to get out as much of the excess liquid

as possible otherwise because of its wet when 
you go to pound it it will actually splash in

your face and it's not fun when that happens I've 
had that have a meal a little walking by somebody

who was making curry paste and you can actually 
smell the spiciness okay we'll put that in our

instrument so that's our ingredient number one 
okay gradient number two let's see we've got a

heaping quarter cup of shallots now in Thailand 
we use a different variety of shallots they're

much much smaller about this eyes of a marble and 
and they're a little more pungent but we make you

know may do it whatever we have here so heaping 
quarter cup three tablespoons of chopped garlic

again in Thailand we use what we call Thai 
garlic which are tiny about the size of you

know the size of my pinky tip here next you've got 
three three tablespoons of chopped two lemongrass

actually chopped this straight from frozen try 
to use the purple part because that's the more

fragrant part and then we've got a tablespoon of 
chopped galangal I also chopped the straight from

frozen and I've got a teaspoon of cilantro route 
now cilantro route is pretty much the root of the

cilantro plant looks like this it's it's a shame 
that in North America they use cilantro so so much

but no one uses natural roots I actually have 
to go to specialty time store to get these if

you can't find them you can use cilantro stems 
instead now this smells just like cilantro but

it's very very fruit so much more fragrant and 
and the smell is stronger and it actually the

smell last longer in cooking as well so we've got 
that and then we've got kaffir lime zest now use

give your lime leaves in many of my recipes this 
is what the fruit looks like here and you just

take a knife and take out the green bit of the 
skin try not to get too much of the white part

and then chop it up this is actually really good 
for your hair I'm actually using a kaffir lime

shampoo like that so there is juice in there but 
there's not a whole lot of juice so that's why

we don't really use a juice for cooking very much 
peppercorns white peppercorns about a quarter of a

teaspoon shrimp paste about a teaspoon of shrimp 
paste now this is in every single curry and one

would say that it's quite smelly or pungent but 
Thai people think it actually smells good comes

in a tough like this and it's a little bit of 
a misnomer because it's not made from shrimp

it's actually made from krills so they crying up 
the crows with salt and fermented for months and

months months and then it becomes this wonderful 
piece and and it's quite salty so it's actually a

salting agent for this and then lastly a teaspoon 
of coarse sea salt using sea salt because sea salt

tastes better tastes like the ocean and course 
because the coarse grain helps add abrasiveness

to to the grinding so the instrument we're using 
today as you can see is a stone mortar and pestle

now I want to stress the fact that it is the stone 
one is the heavy duty one this clay and wood one

is a light duty one that won't work as well for 
this because there's so much to grind up and you

really want to find this work this is for piyah 
salad or for crushing grinding light things like

garlic and peanuts and things like that but 
it won't work quite as well for this recipe

you can do this in a food processor 
if you want and it'll speed everything

up but I think if you have time there's 
something wonderful about manually doing

it and putting your effort and energy 
and time into it and gradually witness

the transformation because when you do 
that you can take more pride and and

you just tend to enjoy that much more 
when you put effort and time into it

the order in which things go in actually matter 
in a sense that it'll make it harder or easier

for your grinding process the chiles you want to 
start with the things that's hardest to grind and

the easiest things the grind will go in last 
the chilies is actually the hardest because

the skin is very stubborn so we're going to 
add our salt which would be um sort of the

friction then help break down the chili now are 
you doing the chili don't look at it and cover it

up with your hand love it so that if something 
does jump out it doesn't jump out in your face

look at it every wish now the next thing to 
go in is any dry spices so for this recipe

we've got the white peppercorns some recipes 
like for Panang curry or massaman curry will

call for cumin and coriander this is where you 
will add that as well and then we're going to

go in with the fibrous tough herbs so we've 
got the kaffir lime zest and cilantro roots

will go in first you want to do this a little 
bit at a time if you put in all this at once

it'll take that much longer to be harder to 
get everything to grind and then next we're

going in with the lemongrass and vigeland oh 
okay now we get to this point we're going to

go in with our soft herbs the shallots and 
the garlic just going to do it one at a time

garlic and then we're also gonna add 
our final ingredient shrimp paste and

with garlic and it looks like we're done 
so let me show you what this looks like

now you can store this about a week or so 
in the fridge but to really preserve if

you're going to use it in the near 
future you can actually create it

there's our red curry paste and now you can use 
this in any recipes that call for red curry paste

I've got a couple of recipes the peanut sauce 
for snacking peanut sauce uses it and also pop

thinking also uses red curry paste that's it 
thanks for tuning in and I will see you next
